title: Desperate to sell? The record-breaking house that estate agents can't wait for you to see
text:
3,545.00 -29.00 
Lofties, in Worksop, breaks the record for the most photos uploaded onto Britain's biggest property site, with 142 pictures included in the advert 
One of the best parts of house-hunting is snooping around other people’s homes by browsing photos online. 
Property experts recommend displaying nine or 10 pictures when trying to sell a house to let potential buyers get a feel for the place. 
But one estate agency was so enthusiastic about a “stunning” five bedroom detached house on their books that they broke property records - by uploading a colossal 142 images with their advert. 
That’s more pictures than any previous listing on Britain’s biggest property search website, Rightmove . The last record-holder included 129 photos. 
The house has its own tennis court (Blenheim Park Estates) 
The house, Lofties, in Worksop, near Sheffield, is on the market at just under £3m and has plenty of rooms for the agents, Blenheim Park Estates, to show off. 
Included in the 142 image photo album are snaps of the five ensuite bedrooms, home cinema, indoor and outdoor swimming pools, sauna and gym. 
The luxurious pad also comes with eight acres of grounds, including tennis courts, a secret garden and fire pit. 
Ideal for rainy days: the home cinema (Blenheim Park Estates) 
Also in the vast back garden is a summerhouse, once used as a stables before being converted to a games room and annexe. 
The master bedroom comes with an oak-panelled dressing room and ensuite with Nordic steam shower. 
Rather than make the effort of going out, the new owners could stay in and have a drink at their very own bar. 
The home has indoor and outdoor pools (Blenheim Park Estates) 
Aline Newton, Sales Manager at Blenheim Park Estates said: “The property totally deserves as many photographs as you can produce. 
“It’s an absolutely stunning property. The standard of the interior is so high and it really does have to be viewed to be appreciated. 
"It offers so much - five ensuite bedrooms, a fantastic state of the art kitchen.” 
The owners evidently like to keep fit with their own gym in the house (Blenheim Park Estates) 
But experts from Rightmove (LSE: RMV.L - news ) warned that including too many photos with a property listing can be self-defeating. 
Having too few pictures puts people off, but so can having too many. 
Miles Shipside, commercial director at Rightmove said there were “some interesting dynamics at play”. 
The house has sprawling grounds (Blenheim Park Estates) 
“Sometimes to impress potential sellers the agent will take a lot of photographs to say, ‘look how much time and effort I have spent marketing this property’," MrShipside said. 
“It can be a law of negative returns. People’s attention spans are relatively short if you give everything away about a property people might not go and see it. 
“You want people to be excited about what they see on the internet and then go and visit it.” 
Rooms come with view of the expansive gardens (Blenheim Park Estates) 
Rightmove chief executive Nick McKittrick said: “We have run seminars across the country for our agent customers where we get 100 or so of our customers together and we talk about internet marketing. 
“What we find is if you have around about nine or 10 images that seems to be the optimum.” 
There is even a fire pit in the garden (Blenheim Park Estates)
